course_info:
PHY203: ELEMENTARY PHYSICS I (Fall 2024)
Instructor: Miquel Dorca
Office Location: 211 East Hall
Email: miquel@uri.edu
Office Hours: MWF 12:30pm -1:00pm
Course Description: Calculus-based introduction to Newtonian mechanics. Kinematics and dynamics of particles and systems of particles, conservation laws, rotational motion, gravitation, and oscillatory motion.
Prerequisites: Credit or concurrent enrollment in MTH 141 and concurrent enrollment in PHY 273.
Intended for: Science and engineering majors.
Textbook: University Physics (Open Stax), 1st Edition, Volume 1. Available at https://openstax.org/subjects/science.
Course Goals:
1. Develop a conceptual and quantitative understanding of kinematics.
2. Develop a conceptual and quantitative understanding of forces.
3. Develop a conceptual and quantitative understanding of work, energy, and energy conservation.
4. Develop a conceptual and quantitative understanding of linear momentum and linear momentum conservation.
5. Develop a conceptual and quantitative understanding of rotational kinematics, rotational dynamics, and angular momentum conservation.
6. Develop a conceptual and quantitative understanding of oscillations and simple harmonic motion.
General Education Areas: Satisfies URI's general education areas: "Scientific, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematical Disciplines" (Full); and "Mathematical, Statistical, or Computational Strategies" (Partial).
Learning Outcomes:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the basic concepts of classical mechanics.
2. Apply a conceptual understanding of classical mechanics to physics problems.
3. Develop problem-solving strategies and techniques appropriate to classical mechanics.
4. Carry out quantitative solutions of classical mechanics problems.
5. Carry out, analyze, and present the results of classical mechanics laboratory experiments.
Instructor Contact Details: Email - miquel@uri.edu; Office Hours - MWF 12:30pm -1:00pm.
Brightspace: Used for class announcements and all lectures will be posted. Remote lectures will be given asynchronously on Brightspace if needed.
Course Grade: Based on a maximum of 1200 points: unit exams 400 points, final exam 400 points, homework 150 points, recitation 250 points.
Grading Scheme: A(93-100); A-(90-93); B+(87-90); B(83-87); B-(80-83); C+(77-80); C(73-77); C-(70-73); D+(67-70); D(60-67); F(<60).
schedule:
Lecture Times: MWF 1pm-1:50pm (Section 1) at East Hall Auditorium.
Lab Sessions: PHY273 Laboratory Schedule:
- Intro lab: 9/9-13
- Motion in 1D (free fall): 9/16-20
- Motion in one 1D (analysis): 9/23-27
- Motion in 2D (projectiles): 9/30-10/4
- Motion in 2D (analysis): 10/7-11
- Newton's laws: 10/14-18
- Conservation of Energy: 10/21-25
- Collisions (experiment): 10/28-11/1
- Collisions (analysis) 2 weeks: 11/4-15
- Ballistic Pendulum: 11/18-22
- No labs: 11/25-29
- Rotational dynamics: 12/2-12/6
- Make-up Lab (Pendulum): 12/12 (Reading Day)
Exam Dates:
- Exam #1 (Chaps. 1,3,4) on Fri., 09/27 at TBA
- Exam #2 (Chaps. 5-8) on Fri., 10/25 at TBA
- Exam #3 (Chaps. 9-11,15) on Wed., 12/11 at TBA
Final Exam: TBA
Course Meeting Patterns: MWF 1pm-1:50pm
Locations: East Hall Auditorium for lectures; Room 112 for recitations.
Remote Sessions: Asynchronous on Brightspace on November 25th, 27th, December 2nd if needed due to weather cancellations.

Assignment Details:
- Submitted through WebAssign by 10 p.m. on due dates.
- 5 submission attempts per assignment.
- 4-day extension with a 10-point penalty available once per assignment after due date.
- Each student receives different problem sets on WebAssign.
- 2-week free grace period for initial setup.
WebAssign Access:
- Enroll using class key: uri 1373 1043.
- Purchase WebAssign at http://webassign.net/student.html.
- Specific links for OpenStax/WebAssign and pricing provided.

Recitation Assignments:
- Register for a recitation section of PHY273.
- Recitation grade up to 250 points.
- Correctly solve 3 problems per recitation for full credit.
- Additional problems can compensate for missed problems in previous sessions.
exams:
Examinations:
- Three unit exams and a cumulative final exam.
- All exams are closed book; no resources allowed.
- Calculators permitted.
- Formula sheets allowed: 1 sheet per unit exam, 3 sheets for final exam.
- Unit Exam #1 (Chaps. 1,3,4) on Fri., 09/27.
- Unit Exam #2 (Chaps. 5-8) on Fri., 10/25.
- Unit Exam #3 (Chaps. 9-11,15) on Wed., 12/11.
- Final Exam: TBA, covers Chaps. 1-11,15 with 3 parts corresponding to unit exams.
- Final Exam scoring policy: If a part score is higher than the corresponding unit exam, it replaces the unit score. Lower scores do not replace.
- Note: Exam schedule and grading scheme may be modified if the course goes remote.

PHY273 Laboratory Exams:
- Make-up Lab: Pendulum on 12/12 (Reading Day).
